definitions.definition: a short thin piece of stiff wire with a sharp point at one end and a round head at the other, used especially for fastening together pieces of cloth when sewing

examples.text: Use pins to keep the patch in place while you sew it on.

definitions.definition: a short thin piece of stiff wire with a sharp point at one end and an item of decoration at the other, worn as jewellery
a piece of jewellery with a pin on the back of it, that can be fastened to your clothes
definitions.labels: (especially North American English)especially in British English

definitions.definition: a type of badge that is fastened with a pin at the back

examples.text: He supports the group and wears its pin on his lapel.

definitions.definition: a piece of steel used to support a bone in your body when it has been broken

examples.text: The pin in her spine will have to be changed as she grows.

definitions.definition: one of the metal parts that stick out of an electric plug and fit into a socket
a wooden or plastic object that is like a bottle in shape and that players try to knock down in games such as bowling
a stick with a flag on top of it, placed in a hole so that players can see where they are aiming for

examples.text: The ball stopped five feet short of the pin.
He’s not as quick on his pins as he used to be.

definitions.definition: a small piece of metal on a hand grenade that stops it from exploding and is pulled out just before the hand grenade is thrown
(to be) very anxious or excited while you are waiting to find out something or see what will happen

examples.text: I've been on pins and needles all week waiting for the results.

definitions.definition: used to say that you would like to do something, even though you know that it would not be sensible

examples.text: I'd kill him for two pins.
For two pins I’d tell her what I really think of her.
The audience was so quiet you could have heard a pin drop.

wordOrigin: late Old English pinn, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch pin ‘pin, peg’, from Latin pinna ‘point, tip, edge’.
